bibl.title: Letter from A.H. Glennan to Henry Rose Carter, January 29, 1917

div1.p: Glennan grants Carter permission to appear as a witness in South Carolina.

div1.head: Letter from A.H. Glennan to Henry Rose Carter, January 29, 1917
div1.opener:
J. R. S.
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
IN REPLYING
ADDRESS THE SURGEON GENERAL
U. S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
BUREAU OF
THE PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
WASHINGTON
January 29, 1917.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Md.
Sir:
div1.p:
The Bureau is in receipt of your letter of the 10th
ultimo, enclosing a communication with the Colleton Cyprus
Company in which request is made for you to appear as a
witness in a court case in South Carolina. The enclosure
mentioned is returned herewith. Reply to your communi-
cation has been deferred pending the receipt of advices
from the State Board of Health of South Carolina and your
report of your preliminary inspections of the Salkehatchie
swamps.

In view of the increased demand for officers to
appear as witnesses in court proceedings it is pertinent
to quote the policy that has been initiated and followed
in previous cases as follows:

“It would not appear advisable that officers of the
Service should be authorized or required to take steps to
qualify as witnesses in particular cases. In questions
under litigation that have a bearing on the public health
-2-
and regarding which officers, by reason of special training
and experience, are competent to testify, it would, however,
appear proper for them to make available to the court their
special knowledge. In the event, therefore, of a summons
or a request being received from the court for the officers
mentioned to appear as witnesses, it appears proper for
them to be authorized to do so, provided no expense will
be incurred by the government.”

In accordance with the above, if a request through
the court is received, insuring the payment of your ex-
penses, authority will be granted to you to respond without
expense to the Government.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, A H Glennan
Acting Surgeon-General. JB
